[[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] | used=2003–2009 | materials= | demolished= | battles=[[Iraq War]] | events= | past_commanders= | garrison= | occupants= Up to 20.000 Iraqi prisoners }} '''Camp Bucca''' ({{lang-ar|سجن بوكا}}) was a detention facility{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7561952.stm |title=US jail guards in Iraq abuse case |accessdate=14 August 2008 |publisher=BBC |date=14 August 2008 }} maintained by the [[United States]] [[military]] in the vicinity of [[Umm Qasr|Umm Qasr, Iraq]]. As of June 2011, a group of entrepreneurial Iraqis and Americans are re-building Camp Bucca as Basra Gateway, a logistic center. The facility was initially called [[Tony Beckley|Camp Freddy]] and used by British Forces to hold Iraqi [[Prisoner of war|prisoners of war]].{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/800mp-bde.htm |title=800th Military Police Brigade |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} After being taken over by the U.S. military (800th Military Police Brigade) in April 2003, it was renamed after [[Ronald Bucca]], a NYC [[Fire Marshal]] who died in the [[11 September 2001 attacks]]. Camp Bucca was built on a site where before the tallest structure of Iraq, a 492 metres high TV mast stood, which might have been used for propaganda TV to Iran.{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/#lang=de&lat=30.059744&lon=47.887779&z=18&m=bs|title=Wikimapia - Let's describe the whole world!|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/#lang=de&lat=30.059744&lon=47.887779&z=18&m=b|title=Wikimapia - Let's describe the whole world!|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/buildings/1249233/umm-qasr-tv-mast-az-zubayr-iraq|title=Umm Qasr TV Mast, Az Zubayr - 1249233 - EMPORIS|first=Emporis|last=GmbH|publisher=}} After the [[Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse|Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal]], many detainees from [[Abu Ghraib prison|Abu Ghraib]] were transferred to Camp Bucca. After a substantial turn-over in the [[command hierarchy|chain of command]] at Camp Bucca and substantial amendments to camp policy, the US military held up Camp Bucca as an example of how a model detention facility should be run.{{cite news|last1=Khalil|first1=Ashraf|title=Camp Bucca Turns 180 Degrees From Abu Ghraib|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jan/19/world/fg-bucca19|accessdate=7 July 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=10 Jan 2005}} A majority of the detainees were reportedly housed in cinder block housing units with wooden roofing rather than tents, while other detainees were held in hasty tent compounds until 2009. Cigarettes, tea, and the opportunity to listen to radio and T.V. programs were used as incentives for good behavior. Some detainees were allowed family visitation from Iraqi relatives not held at the facility. Detainees were provided the opportunity for basic education including reading, writing (both English and Arabic), arithmetic, basic geography and art. Detainees organized and administered their own classes in subjects like literacy and religion, and competed in soccer matches. Soccer matches were encouraged to attempt to promote cooperation and trust between every aspect involved in the camp. Additionally, the internment facility had its own U.S. Army run hospital to serve detainees. It offered comprehensive healthcare. There was an emergency room, internal medicine clinic, optometry clinic, psychiatric services, orthopedic/surgical unit, physical therapy clinic, pharmacy, dental clinic, dietary services and more. Detainees were screened by medics and doctors at the wire, that was right out where the detainees are housed, and then triaged to the hospital for further care. Some detainees were flown to larger medical facilities in Iraq to receive cataract surgery. U.S. Army medical staff was also given training on how to provide care while respecting Muslim traditions. Militants regularly launched rockets into Camp Bucca. The rockets are widely believed to be often provided and set up by Iranians who teach the militants to launch them hours after they've returned to their nearby country (about {{convert|25|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}}).{{citation needed|date=July 2008}} The lethal explosions averaged around 5 per month in a period from September 2007 to late April 2008, with the most intense barrage coming during The Ramadan period (October) when 12 aerial bombs (Believed to be stolen from a British camp in nearby (about {{convert|35|-|40|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on|round=5}}) al Basrah){{citation needed|date=July 2008}} landed in a span of 8 days. On 17 September 2009, The US military announced that the base would be closed.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/library/news/2009/09/sec-090917-afns01.htm |title=Camp Bucca detention center closes in Iraq |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=2009-09-17 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} In December 2010, the U.S. military handed the base to the government of Iraq, who, on the same day, gave Kufan Group of Iraq a license to invest in the new Basra Gateway, to provide a 21st-century logistics hub for Iraq's port. ==Significant events== {{prose|date=November 2014}} ===2003=== During the months of April and May 2003 two prisoners were shot, one killed, by soldiers of the 314th MP Company. One was fired on during a riot, after he attempted to assault a staff-sergeant with a sharpened piece of metal re-bar removed from their housing tents. He was struck in the lower side of his abdomen and died during surgery. The other was fired on by a soldier as he attempted to crawl through barbed wire to obtain a pistol belt (which later turned out to be empty) left behind by a battalion MP when rioting prisoners threw rocks. The prisoner was struck in the leg and abandoned his attempt to reach the pistol belt.{{cn|date=June 2018}} On 18 May 2003, U.S. military forces mistakenly released Mohammed Jawad An-Neifus from the Camp Bucca. An-Neifus is suspected of being involved in the mass murder of thousands of Iraqi [[Shia]]s whose remains were later found at a [[mass grave]]site in the southern city of [[al-Mahawil]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2950398.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Middle East - Iraq killings suspect freed 'in error'|publisher=News.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 November 2014}} ===2004=== On 7 January 2004, a detainee escaped from Camp Bucca. Investigating officers concluded that 'the detainee escaped through an undetected weakness in the wire. Contributing factors were inexperienced guards, lapses in accountability, complacency, lack of leadership presence, poor visibility, and lack of clear and concise communication between the guards and the leadership.' On 12 January 2004, 7 Detainees escaped during the night, 5 were recaptured. On 26 January 2004 3 detainees escaped at night during a period of intense fog. An investigation 'concluded that the detainees crawled under a fence when visibility was only 10–15 meters due to fog'.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/iraq/umm-qasr.htm |title=Umm Qasr |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 19 October 2004, A 26-year-old security internee died of unknown causes.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/news/iraq/2004/10/iraq-041020-centcom01.htm |title=Detainee Dies At Camp Bucca |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=2004-10-20 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} ===2005=== On 5 January 2005, a 31-year-old security internee died of what appears to be natural causes.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/01/mil-050107-mnfi-mnci04.htm |title=Detainee Dies of Apparent Natural Causes |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} In April 2004, Compound 4. A riot broke out in which detainees threw rocks and fashioned weapons out of tent poles. Detainees held a military soldier hostage until the riot was dispelled by the use of lethal force. Four detainees were killed and six were injured. As is standard procedure in all cases of prison riots and the use of lethal force, the matter was investigated by the U.S. Army's Criminal Investigations Division. The investigation concluded that a detainee leader had incited the riot by making an accusation that camp soldiers were stepping on [[Koran]]s during a search for contraband. No soldiers were found guilty of any wrongdoing during the incident.{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/02/18/opinion/web.0218abuse.php?page=3 |title=Jailed 2 years, Iraqi tells of abuse by Americans |date=18 February 2007 |work=International Herald Tribune |accessdate=18 February 2007}} On 5 February 2005, the tabloid paper ''[[New York Daily News]]'' reported that units at Camp Bucca organized and held a [[mud wrestling]] party on 30 October 2004. The party was organized by members of the 160th MP Battalion{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/160mp.htm |title=160th Military Police Battalion |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=1971-01-21 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} and attended by members of the incoming 105th MP Battalion, who were arriving to relieve the members of the 160th. At least three female [[G.I. (military)|GIs]] stripped to their [[undergarments]] and wrestled in a kiddie-pool full of sand and water in front of a crowd of male GIs, and one GI flashed her breasts. About 30 photos of the party, including one of the flasher, have been leaked to the press. The flasher, 19-year-old [[Private First Class|PFC]] Deanna Allen, was demoted for [[indecent exposure]], and reportedly later discharged from the military. On 4 March 2005, Camp Bucca was targeted by 106 mm rocket fire directed from the port of [[Umm Qasr]]. Although no military personnel were injured or killed, a [[Third Country National]] took [[Shrapnel shell|shrapnel]] to the leg. Four rockets targeted Camp Bucca, but only one detonated within the boundaries of the base. {{Wikinews|Guards uncover 600-foot escape tunnel at US prison in Iraq}} On 25 March 2005, a complete [[escape tunnel]] was discovered, though no prisoners had yet managed to escape.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/meast/03/25/iraq.tunnel/ |title=Escape tunnel found at Iraqi prison |publisher=CNN.com |date=25 March 2005 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 1 April 2005, two Iraqis and four US prison guards were wounded in a [[riot]] at Camp Bucca near the southern town of Umm Qasr.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/04/mil-050404-mnfi-mnci01.htm |title=Multi-national Corps-Iraq/Multi-National Forces-Iraq News Release |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 15 April 2005, a dispute broke out between two groups of detainees at one of the compounds of the Camp Bucca theater internment facility at approximately 11 pm. The fight left one detainee dead, was confined between the detainees in one compound, and was not directed at U.S. forces.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/04/mil-050415-mnfi-mnci03.htm |title=Multi-national Corps-Iraq/Multi-National Forces-Iraq News Release |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 16 April 2005, 11 detainees escaped Camp Bucca by cutting through in the facility's exterior fence and crawling through the unfilled portion of a previously discovered {{convert|600|ft|m|adj=on|order=flip}} escape tunnel. The compound's guards, members of the United States Air Force, were unable to see the detainees cutting through the wire due to tower location. All 11 detainees were later captured by the [[Iraqi police]] and returned to Camp Bucca. On 19 April 2005, a 51-year-old male security detainee at Camp Bucca died of natural causes.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/04/mil-050419-centcom01.htm |title=Results - Casualty Report Generator |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=2005-04-19 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 14 May 2005, a 30-year-old male detainee at Camp Bucca died from a heart attack.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/05/mil-050514-mnfi-mnci02.htm |title=Multi-national Corps-Iraq/Multi-National Forces-Iraq News Release |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 23 May 2005, a fuel truck collapsed the roof of an escape tunnel being dug out of Camp Bucca.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} On 27 July 2005, a 30-year-old male security detainee at Camp Bucca died as a result of renal failure and other organ failure due to chronic malaria.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/07/mil-050728-mnfi02.htm |title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=2005-07-28 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 28 September 2005, SGT Steve Morin Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1146242.html|title=Army Sgt. Steve Morin Jr. Died September 28, 2005 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806000157/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1146242.html|archivedate=6 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} assigned to the 111th Engineer Battalion{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/111eng.htm |title=111th Engineer Battalion |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} and [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] [[Airman 1st Class]] [[Elizabeth Jacobson|Elizabeth N. Jacobson]]{{cite web |url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1146269.html |title=N/K |publisher=Militarycity.com |accessdate=25 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826101154/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1146269.html |archivedate=26 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} assigned to the 17th Security Forces Squadron{{cite web |author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/usaf/17trw.htm |title=17th Training Wing [17th TRW] |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} stationed at Camp Bucca were [[killed in action]] when an [[improvised explosive device]] detonated near their convoy vehicle near the Iraqi town of [[Safwan]]. In October 2005, the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] began the Family Visitation Allowance Program at Camp Bucca. The program provides monetary assistance to families of detainees held at Camp Bucca to help cover part of the traveling and hotel costs required to visit the facility. The benefits are calculated based on the distance between their home and the city of Umm Qasr.{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/htmlall/iraq-stories-040406?opendocument|title=Search results - Resource centre |work=International Committee of the Red Cross|accessdate=25 November 2014}} In December 2006 a similar program was initiated at Camp Shaibe, the British internment facility in Shaibah, near Al Basrah.{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/htmlall/iraq-news-131206?opendocument|title=Search results - Resource centre |work=International Committee of the Red Cross|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 5 October 2005, a 43-year-old male security detainee died of a heart attack.{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/10/mil-051005-mnfi03.htm |title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} On 13 October 2005, eligible detainees at Camp Bucca, Abu Ghraib prison and Camp Cropper were allowed to vote in the Iraqi Constitutional Referendum. The rest of the country voted on 15 October 2005.[http://www.newsobserver.com/24hour/special_reports/iraq/story/2799924p-11428884c.html ]{{dead link|date=July 2014}} On 23 October 2005, a 73-year-old male security detainee died of natural causes at Camp Bucca.{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/10/mil-051024-mnfi02.htm|title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca|author=John Pike |publisher=Globalsecurity.org|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 25 October 2005, it was reported that [[Specialist (rank)|SPC]] Christopher T. Monroe{{cite web |url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1218050.html |title=Army Spc. Christopher T. Monroe Died October 25, 2005 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom |publisher=Militarycity.com |accessdate=25 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826085041/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1218050.html |archivedate=26 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} assigned to the Military Police Battalion{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/785mp.htm |title=785th |author=John Pike |publisher=Globalsecurity.com |accessdate=25 November 2014}} stationed at Camp Bucca was killed when he was struck by a vehicle operated by Erinys International while pulling security for the United States convoy which was stopped due to an Iraqi vehicle which flipped over while trying to avoid the convoy in the vicinity of [[Al Basrah]], [[Iraq]]. In October 2007, a lawsuit was filed in [[Houston]], [[Texas]] by the father of SPC Monroe against the British private security firm [[Erinys International]]. In the lawsuit, Monroe's father alleges that his son actually died after he was struck by a vehicle operated by Erinys International. The lawsuit alleges Erinys personnel passed through a checkpoint where they were warned that there were more troops ahead of them but despite the warning proceeded in the dark at a high rate of speed with only [[parking lights]] on until they struck Monroe. Monroe was dismounted and standing guard near the 5-ton vehicle he was driving providing security after the convoy he was in stopped to render assistance to an Iraqi who had been involved in a car accident. The force of the accident sheared Monroe's right leg off and threw him 30–40 feet in the air. Monroe later "died on a Medavac helicopter en route to Shalib Airbase". In a statement in response to the lawsuit, a spokesperson for the company stated "It was a very tragic accident for which Erinys and its employees have been thoroughly exonerated".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/Iraq/Story/0,,2201538,00.html|title=US soldier's family brings legal action against British private security firm |date=30 October 2007 |work=The Guardian |author=Suzanne Goldenberg |accessdate=30 October 2007 |location=London}}{{cite web |url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664447&imw=Y |title=AP: Family of U.S. Soldier Killed in Iraq Sues Private Contractor |date=28 October 2007 |work=[[Editor & Publisher]] |accessdate=30 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809165918/http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003664447&imw=Y |archivedate=9 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} On 5 November 2005, a 65-year-old male security detainee died of natural causes at Camp Bucca.{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/11/mil-051105-mnfi04.htm|title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca|author=John Pike |publisher=Globalsecurity.org|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 12 December 2005, nearly 90 percent of all eligible security detainees in Multi-National Forces-Iraq Theater Internment Facilities participated in the democratic vote on the Iraqi National Ballot.{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2005/12/mil-051212-mnfi03.htm|title=Detainee Voter Turn Out Overwhelming|author=John Pike|publisher=Globalsecurity.org|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 23 December 2005, Camp Bucca received rocket fire from behind an area dubbed the "Sniper House"; no injuries were reported. ===2006=== On 1 January 2006, 3 detainees escaped Camp Bucca by cutting through the facilities exterior fence. Two of the detainees were later captured by the Iraqi police and returned to Camp Bucca. On 7 January 2006, SGT Nathan Field{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1459362.html|title=Army Sgt. Nathan R. Field Died January 7, 2006 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827040721/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1459362.html|archivedate=27 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} and SPC Robert Johnson{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1459359.html|title=Army Spc. Robert T. Johnson Died January 7, 2006 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826085100/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1459359.html|archivedate=26 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} assigned to the 414th Military Police Company were killed in a non-combat vehicle accident just outside Camp Bucca.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/iraq/casualties/2006-01-03-jan-06-toll_x.htm|title=U.S Casualties in Iraq|date=14 March 2006|work=USA Today|accessdate=1 April 2007}} On 7 March 2006, a 36-year-old detainee died of natural causes.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2006/03/mil-060307-afps01.htm|title=DefenseLINK News: Detainee Dies at Camp Bucca; Coalition Forces Kill Two Terrorists|author=John Pike|work=Global Security|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 15 March 2006, Camp Bucca received rocket fire; no injuries were reported. On 26 March 2006, a 25-year-old detainee died as the result of injuries suffered in a detainee on detainee fight. 11 May 2006, detainees initiated a multiple compound riot that included the burning of their living quarters, burning a Humvee and assaults on other detainees. The reported cause of the riot was detainees being unhappy that their housing areas were searched and that a Qu'ran with Takferi writing had been placed in a clear evidence bag that the detainees presumed was a trash bag. The riot started around 7 am in compound 10. The initial incident was stopped within an hour but around 11 am the TIF exploded with multiple compound riots. Multiple weapons were found during initial search, and based on the detainees use of weapons against the guard force, multiple weapons were confiscated during additional searches initiated because of the riot.{{cite web |url=http://www.croughton.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123048185 |author=Tech Sgt. Keith Houin |title=Iraq actions earn Captain Bronze Star |date=10 April 2007 |work=U.S. Air Force Public Affairs |accessdate=28 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706173116/http://www.croughton.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123048185 |archivedate=6 July 2007 |df=dmy-all }} On 30 May 2006, Camp Bucca received rocket fire; no injuries were reported. On 2 June 2006, the Army opened an Iraqi-based detention center training facility at [[Fort Leonard Wood (military base)|Fort Leonard Wood]] [[Missouri]] called Camp Charlie. This new facility is modeled after the theater internment facility at Camp Bucca. A similar facility was opened at [[Fort Leavenworth]] in August 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2006/08/mil-060823-arnews01.htm|title=New facility to help MPs learn detainee handling |author=John Pike|work=Global Security|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 1 July 2006, Airman 1st Class Carl Jerome Ware Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1930456.html|title=Air Force Airman 1st Class Carl Jerome Ware Jr. : Died July 1, 2006 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedoms|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805150021/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/1930456.html|archivedate=5 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} of the [[886 Expeditionary Security Forces Squadron|886th Expeditionary Security Force Squadron]] assigned to Camp Bucca died of non-combat related injuries. Initial reports stated that the airmen was killed by an accidental discharge of a gun being cleaned by another airman;{{cite web |url=http://starbulletin.com/2006/07/04/news/story15.html |title=Hickam airman killed in shooting accident |date=4 July 2006 |work=Star Bulletin |accessdate=20 February 2007}} however in February 2007, it was reported that Airman 1st Class Kyle J. Dalton, of the 15th Security Forces Squadron, [[Hickam Air Force Base]], [[Hawaii]], had been charged on 30 November 2007 with one count of [[murder]] and failure to obey a [[Lawful orders|lawful order]] in relation to the shooting. Dalton also faced a charge of [[assault]] for a separate incident that occurred on 30 June 2006 involving Ware and another airman.{{cite web |url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2007/02/AFmurdercharge070219/|title=Airman charged with murdering fellow airman |date=20 February 2007 |work=Army Times|accessdate=20 February 2007}} Dalton, who was deployed in the [[Middle East]] at the time the charges were brought, had an [[Article 32 hearing]] and was [[Courts-martial in the United States|Court-martialed]] on 23 April 2007 at [[Langley Air Force Base]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypress.com/news/nn-courtmartial,0,3608931.story?track=rss|title=Langley AFB to be site for court-martial|date=23 February 2007|work=Daily Press|accessdate=23 February 2007}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web |url=http://www.delawareonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070411/NEWS/704110370|title=Death of airman brings murder charge |date=11 April 2007 |work=Delaware Online|first=Erik |last=Holmes|accessdate=11 April 2007}} As part of a plea bargain deal, Dalton pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter and violating a lawful general regulation by drawing or aiming a firearm when deadly force was unnecessary. Dalton was sentenced to 10 years in prison, given a [[dishonorable discharge]], reduced in rank from [[Senior Airman]] to [[Airman Basic]] and ordered to forfeit all pay and allowances. Dalton admitted to the court that he tracked Ware with his pistol in the barracks and pulled the trigger thinking the weapon was unloaded. He also admitted that he had previously aimed a loaded [[M4 Carbine|M-4 carbine]] at another airman.{{cite web |url=http://www.philly.com/inquirer/local/nj/20070425_Airman_gets_10_years_for_killing_comrade.html|title=Airman gets 10 years for killing comrade |date=25 April 2007|work=Associated Press via The Philadelphia Inquirer|accessdate=26 April 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929173727/http://www.philly.com/inquirer/local/nj/20070425_Airman_gets_10_years_for_killing_comrade.html |archivedate=29 September 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://content.hamptonroads.com/story.cfm?story=123410&ran=150623&tref=y|title=At Langley, airman pleads guilty in death of bunkmate in Iraq|date=24 April 2007|author=Louis Hansen|work=The Virginian-Pilot|accessdate=26 April 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231541/http://content.hamptonroads.com/story.cfm?story=123410&ran=150623&tref=y|archivedate=26 September 2007|df=dmy-all}} In July 2006, it was announced that the Army's inspector general had requested an investigation to determine if an [[Anti-Deficiency Act]] violation occurred during the building of the detention facility.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/2006/sigir-jul06_appdx-l.pdf|format=PDF|title=Detailed summary of Other Agency oversight|work=Global Security|accessdate=26 November 2014}} The Anti-Deficiency Act provides that no one can obligate the Government to make payments for which money has not already been authorized.{{cite web|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=browse_usc&docid=Cite:+31USC1341|title=US Government Printing Office|work=Frwebgate|accessdate=25 November 2014}} The inspector general's report was released to Congress on 30 January 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/2007/sigir-jan07_report.htm|title=Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction (SIGIR) 30 January 2007 Quarterly and Semiannual Report to Congress |date=30 January 2007 |work=Global Security |accessdate=11 April 2007}} and in it concluded: "Army personnel associated with funding of Phases I and II construction of the Internment Facility at Camp Bucca, Iraq, did not implement sufficient controls to ensure military compliance with applicable laws and regulations. As a result, there were two ADA violations with the FY 2004 Army Operation and Maintenance Appropriation. [[United States Department of Defense|DoD]] OGC (Office of General Counsel) is completing its review and expects to sign out the report to the DoD [[Comptroller]] in the second quarter of FY 2007."{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/2007/sigir-jan07_appdx_k.pdf|title=Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction (SIGIR) 30 January 2007 Quarterly and Semiannual Report to Congress Appendix K|date=30 January 2007|work=Global Security|accessdate=11 April 2007}} On 12 October 2006, an Iraqi detainee died from a heart attack. The detainee had been hospitalized since 5 October after complaining of chest pains. An autopsy will be performed to determine the cause of death.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/15/world/middleeast/15iraq.html?em&ex=1161144000&en=ebec7c6074fc33be&ei=5087%0A|title=26 Killed By Revenge Attack|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=25 November 2014}} On 16 October, two airmen from the 586th Expeditionary [[United States Air Force Security Forces|Security Forces]] Squadron Area Security Operations team assigned to Camp Bucca suffered injuries when an improvised explosive device exploded near their [[Humvee]] in the vicinity of Safwan. Both airmen survived the attack and were later awarded the [[Purple Heart]] medal. On 19 October 2006, an Iraqi detainee died from natural causes. On 25 November 2006, American forces announced that a detainee died of natural causes. The detainee had been hospitalized since 23 November after complaining of chest pains.{{cite web|url=http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=18487|title=Blasts rock Baghdad despite curfew|work=Middle East Online|date=26 November 2006|accessdate=25 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714181204/http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/?id=18487#|archive-date=14 July 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On 4 December 2006, American forces announced that a detainee died of natural causes. The detainee had been treated in the facility's hospital since 17 November 2006 for kidney and heart problems. Including two detainees that died the previous week at [[Camp Cropper]], this was the fourth detainee in coalition custody to die within a two-week period. On 24 December 2006, Two Detainees attempted an escape from one of the U.S. Navy staffed compounds during the dense seasonal fog. One of detainees was allegedly an I.E.D. maker.[http://www.news.com.au/story/0,10117,20976161-1702,00.html News] {{dead link|date=November 2014}} ===2007=== On 17 January 2007, [[US Navy]] [[Petty Officer Second Class]] Joseph D. Alomar,{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2500925.html|title=Navy Operations Specialist 2nd Class Joseph D. Alomar|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091225092532/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2500925.html|archivedate=25 December 2009|df=dmy-all}} a member of Navy Provisional Detainee BN 2, assigned to Camp Bucca died of non-combat related injuries. The sailor is reported to have died from a gunshot wound to the head.{{cite web|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=9194&Itemid=21|title=Sailor dies in non-combat related incident|date=18 January 2007|publisher=Multi-National Corps – Iraq Public Affairs Office |accessdate=18 January 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.1010wins.com/pages/187356.php?contentType=4&contentId=292838 |title=Sailor From Brooklyn Dies in Iraq|date=21 January 2007|publisher=CBS Radio|accessdate=21 January 2007}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.defenselink.mil/Releases/Release.aspx?ReleaseID=10415|title=DoD Identifies Navy Casualty|date=21 January 2007|publisher=U.S. Department of Defense|accessdate=21 January 2007}} On 11 February 2007 SPC Dennis L. Sellen Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2555590.html|title=Army Spc. Dennis L. Sellen Jr. Died February 11, 2007 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827033050/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2555590.html|archivedate=27 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} of the 1st Battalion, 185th Infantry Regiment was accidentally shot and killed by a fellow soldier who was cleaning his weapon after a mission. The incident is currently being investigated.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-sellen1apr01,1,7794401.story?track=rss&ctrack=1&cset=true|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130128010809/http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-sellen1apr01,1,7794401.story?track=rss&ctrack=1&cset=true|dead-url=yes|archive-date=28 January 2013|title=Army National Guard Spc. Dennis L. Sellen Jr., 20, Newhall; killed in gun accident in Iraq|date=1 April 2007 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=8 April 2007}} {{cite web|url=http://www.estripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=44951|title=Elements of the 1st Battalion, 185th Infantry Regiment, of the California Army National Guard, arrive at Camp Bucca, Iraq, to conduct area security operations.|date=8 April 2007|work=Stars and Stripes|accessdate=8 April 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212205204/http://www.estripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=44951|archivedate=12 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} On 2 March 2007 SPC Christopher D. Young,{{cite web|url=http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2602402.html|title=Army Spc. Christopher D. Young Died March 2, 2007 Serving During Operation Iraqi Freedom|publisher=Militarycity.com|accessdate=25 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826081226/http://www.militarycity.com/valor/2602402.html|archivedate=26 August 2009|df=dmy-all}} 20, of Los Angeles, Calif., died in Safwan, Iraq, of wounds sustained when an improvised explosive device detonated near his vehicle. He was assigned to Company C, 3rd Battalion, 160th Infantry Regiment, [[California Army National Guard]], [[San Pedro, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defenselink.mil/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=10578|title=DoD identifies Army casualty|date=5 March 2007|publisher=U.S. Department of Defense|accessdate=10 July 2007}} On 15 March 2007 military officials announced plans to once again expand Camp Bucca and Camp Cropper. Officials stated that this increase in capacity would be necessary to handle the detainees generated from the increased security operations in [[Baghdad]]. At the time of the report, Camp Bucca's detainee population stood at 13,800.{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2007-03-15/news/0703140922_1_camp-bucca-camp-cropper-iraqi|title=U.S. plans to expand detention centers|date=15 March 2007|work=The Washington Post|author=Walter Pincus|accessdate=15 March 2007}} On 26 April 2007, an Iraqi detainee died from what MNFI reports as injuries sustained during an apparent assault by other detainees. He is reported to have been the sixth detainee to have died in MNF-I TIFs as a result of detainee on detainee violence in the past year.{{cite web|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11656&Itemid=128|title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca|date=27 April 2007|publisher=MNFI News Release|accessdate=28 April 2007}} On 9 June 2007, 6 detainees were killed, 68 wounded and one Iraqi [[Corrections Officer]] was wounded when a rocket struck Compound 8, in the Theater Internment Facility located at Camp Bucca.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6737159.stm |title=Six dead in attack on Iraq prison|date=9 June 2007 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=9 June 2007}} On 10 June 2007, a seventh detainee, who had been medically evacuated to [[Balad Air Base]], died from wounds he sustained in the attack.{{cite press release|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12310&Itemid=128|title=Detainee Dies from Indirect Fire Attack Related Injuries |date=13 June 2007|publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq |accessdate=14 June 2007}} On 23 June 2007 an eighth detainee who had been hospitalized in critical condition since the attack, died from [[cardiac arrest]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12491&Itemid=128|title=Detainee Dies from Indirect Fire Attack Related Injuries |date=23 June 2007|publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq |accessdate=24 June 2007}} On 21 June 2007 a security detainee died of cardiac arrest during a routine medical transfer from Camp Cropper to Camp Bucca.{{cite press release|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12492&Itemid=128|title=Detainee dies from cardiac arrest |date=23 June 2007 |publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq |accessdate=24 June 2007}} On 25 June 2007 a soldier assigned to the 178th Infantry was injured when the vehicle he was driving drove over a buried explosive.{{cite news|url=http://www.sj-r.com/sections/news/stories/117695.asp|title=Lanphier grad recovering from war wounds |date=28 June 2007 |author=Amanda Reavy|work=The State Journal-Register |accessdate=29 June 2007}} On 1 July 2007, a detainee died from what is being reported as natural causes while in the intensive care unit at the Theater Internment Facility hospital at Camp Bucca.{{cite press release |url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12672&Itemid=128 |title=Detainee dies from apparent natural causes at Bucca |date=3 July 2007 |publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq|accessdate=4 July 2007}} On 12 July 2007, a detainee died from what is being reported as injuries suffered in an assault by other detainees. This is the second detainee in coalition forces custody to die from detainee on detainee violence within a week.{{cite press release|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12808&Itemid=128|title=Detainee dies at Camp Bucca |date=12 July 2007 |publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq |accessdate=14 July 2007}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.mnf-iraq.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12772&Itemid=128|title=Detainee dies at Camp Cropper |date=10 July 2007 |publisher=Multi-National Force – Iraq |accessdate=14 July 2007}} On the same day, the [[Associated Press]] reported that Camp Bucca was among several sites in Iraq that had sensitive information posted on non-secure web sites. The Camp Bucca documents, posted on the web site of [[CH2M Hill|CH2M Hill Companies]] of [[Meridian, Colorado]] revealed locations of where prisoners are held, locations of fuel tanks, and the locations of security fences, guard towers and other security measures. The company has subsequently added password protection to its site.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/computersecurity/2007-07-12-mililtary-online-security_N.htm?csp=34|title=Military files left unprotected online |date=12 July 2007 |author=Mike Baker|work=[[USA Today]]|agency=Associated Press |accessdate=12 July 2007}} In August 2007, two separate news articles reported Camp Bucca's detainee populate stood at approximately 20,000 inmates.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20200546/site/newsweek/page/0/|title=Scared Straight: Iraqi Style |date=9 August 2007 |author=Babak Dehghanpisheh|publisher=[[MSNBC.com]]|work=Newsweek |accessdate=2 September 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909142258/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/20200546/site/newsweek/page/0/ |archivedate=9 September 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestate.com/local/story/154356.html|title=Troops embrace home: After a year in Iraq, soldiers look forward to vacations, soul food |date=24 August 2007 |author=Noelle Phillips|work=The State|location=South Carolina |accessdate=2 September 2007}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In October 2007, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) announced it had suspended its visits to Camp Bucca due to the deteriorating security situation in the area. The ICRC visits all detention facilities in Iraq to monitor the conditions detainees are receiving and make recommendations where they perceive improvements could be made. To maintain their neutral status, they refuse coalition security when traveling in Iraq, which causes them to occasionally suspend visits when they deem conditions too hazardous for their personnel.{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/htmlall/iraq-update-300607?opendocument|title=Iraq: ICRC activities, April to July 2007 |date=4 October 2007 |publisher=[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] Press Release |accessdate=4 October 2007}} On 31 October 2007, it was announced that Camp Bucca would be expanded once again to increase its capacity from 20,000 to 30,000 detainees. The $110 million project will be overseen by The [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] and would include $17.6 million retrofit of "13 existing compounds to add concrete pads to prevent tunneling, better segregation areas, and better shower and latrine facilities" as well as new housing, a waste water treatment plant, a water treatment plant and a $3.2 million brick factory for prisoner labor.{{cite web |url=http://www.estripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=49911 |title=Prison camp in Iraq once listed to close now sees major upgrades |date=31 October 2007 |work=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]] |accessdate=31 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212205214/http://www.estripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=49911 |archivedate=12 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} On 27 Oct 2007, a Security Team was traveling from Umm Qsar when they came under attack by RPGs. One US Soldier was killed and three US military members were injured. On 20 November 2007, a security convoy operated by personnel from the 887th ESFS was traveling north of Safwaan city, Iraq from Camp Bucca was struck by an IED. On 23 November 2007, a riot originated in compound 31 and spread to compound 32. The guards were able to quell the riots and there were no casualties. ===2008=== On 1 January 2008, the base was attacked with rocket fire launched from the nearby city of Umm Qasr and no injuries were reported. British counter artillery returned fire as a show of force. The returned fire landed in empty desert close to Umm Qasr. USAF QRF units also responded to search the area for the personnel responsible for launching the rockets at the base. On 8 January 2008, a security convoy operated by personnel from the 887th ESFS traveling to Umm Qasr, Iraq from Camp Bucca was struck by an EFP/IED, injuring three coalition forces and a local national. On 14 February 2008, The 72nd Military Police Company arrived at Camp Bucca, They took over control of the Detainee Air Transportation Mission (DAT) from the USAF. {{clarify|date=July 2012}}{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} On 24 February 2008, Camp Bucca was attacked with rocket fire that killed one [[AAFES]] employee and wounded several other civilian contractors. The rocket attack came less than a week after a convoy from Camp Bucca was attacked by an improvised explosive device. No one was seriously injured in that attack.{{cite web |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/article.aspx?articleID=20080227_1_A1_hTheO68646 |title=45th faces insurgent attacks |date=27 February 2008 |work=[[Tulsa World]] |author=Ben Fenwick |accessdate=27 February 2008}} On 13 June 2008, members of the 887 ESFS, while standing down on a possible IED, came under a complex attack which included a VBIED. This type of attack was the first of its kind reported near Camp Bucca, and no injuries were reported.{{citation needed|date=August 2008}} In August 2008, it was announced that 6 sailors had been charged and would face courts-martial for abusing detainees at Camp Bucca. The abuse allegedly occurred on 14 May and involved beatings of two detainees and the sealing of eight detainees in a cell filled with pepper spray while the cells' ventilation was secured. The abuse apparently occurred after some detainees attacked guards, spitting on them and throwing containers filled with human waste at them. Seven other sailors received [[Nonjudicial punishment|non-judicial punishment]] for failing to report the incidents. Two had their charges dismissed, and the remainder were reduced in rank or faced suspended punishment.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/iraq/2008-08-14-detainees-Iraq_N.htm?csp=34 |title=U.S. Navy: 6 sailors accused of abusing detainees in Iraq |date=14 August 2008 |work=[[USA Today]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=14 August 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2008/09/navy_buccahearing_090408/|title=Hearing postponed for chief accused of abuse |date=5 September 2008 |work=[[Navy Times]] |author=Chris Amos |accessdate=7 September 2008}} In November 2008, the 6 sailors faced an [[article 32 hearing]] at [[Naval Air Station Jacksonville]] on charges of conspiracy, cruelty and maltreatment and making false official statements. [[Damage Controlman]] 2nd Class Adam M. White, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and assault and was sentenced to 89 days confinement and reduction of two pay grades. Adams claims he and other sailors participated in the beating of two detainees at the direction of Chief [[Aviation Structural Mechanic]] Tracy Necaise because the prisoners spit and threw feces at guards. Necaise's attorney blamed upper-level Navy officers for the incident because they assigned the sailors to Camp Bucca without any prior experience working in law enforcement or detention facilities. Necaise and the remaining sailors pleaded not guilty and could face trial in 2009.{{cite web |url=http://wokv.com/localnews/2008/11/sailor-admits-assaulting-detai.html |title=Sailor Admits Assaulting Detainee in Iraq |date=14 November 2008 |publisher=[[WOKV]] |author=Jared Halpern |accessdate=16 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103124403/http://wokv.com/localnews/2008/11/sailor-admits-assaulting-detai.html |archivedate=3 January 2010 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.navytimes.com/news/2008/11/navy_detainee_abuse_111408w/|title=Hearing ends in detainee abuse case |date=14 November 2008 |work=[[Navy Times]] |author=Andrew Tilghman |accessdate=16 November 2008}} ===2009=== On 17 September 2009 Camp Bucca closed down detainee operations. The "SUPERMAX" security row known as "Waterfront" manned by the US Navy NPDB (Naval Provisional Detainee Battalion) was in charge of the custody of the most dangerous detainees, and the last to be closed, with Compound 16 having the remaining 180 detainees either transferred to the U.S. military's [[Camp Cropper]] detention facility near Baghdad International Airport (BIAP) or to an Iraqi, Navy, and Army manned prison at Camp Taji north of Baghdad. NPDB 6 was attached to the US Army 306th Military Police Battalion, commanded by LTC Kenneth King. This was the last Navy unit to handle detainee operations in Camp Bucca. ==Role in the growth of ISIS== Camp Bucca has been described as playing an important role in shaping the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].{{cite news|last1=McCoy|first1=Terrence|title=How the Islamic State evolved in an American prison|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/11/04/how-an-american-prison-helped-ignite-the-islamic-state/|accessdate=5 November 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=4 November 2014}} The detention of large numbers of Jihadists and ex-Ba’athists during the [[Iraqi insurgency (2003–11)|Iraqi insurgency]] provided them with the opportunity to forge alliances and learn from each other, combining the ideological fervour of the former with the organizational skills of the latter.{{cite web |author1=Richard Barrett|title=The Islamic State|url=http://soufangroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/TSG-The-Islamic-State-Nov14.pdf |website=soufangroup.com|publisher=The Soufan Group|accessdate=12 December 2014|date=November 2014|quote=The alliance between members of AQI and ex-Ba’athist was also strengthened by many of them finding themselves thrown together in United States detention centers in Iraq such as Camp Bucca.}}{{cite news|author1=Martin Chulov|title=Isis: the inside story|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/11/-sp-isis-the-inside-story|accessdate=11 December 2014|work=The Guardian|date=11 December 2014|quote=We could never have all got together like this in Baghdad, or anywhere else,” he told me. “It would have been impossibly dangerous. Here, we were not only safe, but we were only a few hundred metres away from the entire al-Qaida leadership}} Former Camp Bucca detainees who went on to become leaders in the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] include Abu Mohammed al-Adnani, detained between 2005 and 2010 during the Iraq conflict and who is now an ISIS senior leader, its chief spokesman and is said to be running the entire country of Syria. Al-Adnani, in 2014, called for lone wolf attacks throughout the world and is thought to be the inspiration for terrorist attacks throughout France. He was killed in an airstrike in Northern Syria on 31 August 2016.CNN article of 7 January 2016 Others include [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]], the leader of the ISIL; [[Abu Muslim al-Turkmani]], al-Baghdadi's deputy; [[Haji Bakr]], who spearheaded ISIL's expansion into Syria; [[Abu Abdulrahman al-Bilawi]], the military leader responsible for planning the [[Fall of Mosul|seizure of Mosul]]; and [[Abu Ayman al-Iraqi]], another senior military leader. [[Abu Mohammad al-Julani]], who founded the Syrian Al Qaeda affiliate [[al-Nusra Front]], was also a Camp Bucca detainee.{{cite web| title= Elusive Al-Qaeda leader in Syria stays in shadows| url= http://www.timesofisrael.com/elusive-al-qaeda-leader-in-syria-stays-in-shadows/ |website = Times of Israel| date = 4 November 2013| accessdate = 15 June 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal|War|Military of the United States}} * [[Lisa Girman]] * [[List of United Kingdom Military installations used during Operation Telic]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{External links|date=October 2013}} {{commonscat}} * [https://archive.is/20130117124822/http://www.baghdadinvest.com/Kufan_Group_Baghdad_Iraq.html Kufan Group current developer of Camp Bucca] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1TDtVX9NBN8 Video of riots at Camp Bucca] * [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4894001 Executive summary of Taguba report] MSNBC.com * [http://www.boston.com/news/world/middleeast/articles/2004/05/11/memo_iraq_abuse_was_vigilante_justice?mode=PF Memo: Iraq abuse was 'vigilante justice']: Boston.com * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070218092420/http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/278199p-238353c.html "Female soldiers dress down & get dirty for mud romps": NY Daily News] * [https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-02-18-mud-soldier_x.htm?csp=34 Mud-wrestling soldier to be dismissed from service: USA Today] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/23/AR2005082301525.html In Iraq Jail, Resistance Goes Underground: Washington Post] * [http://www.katv.com/news/stories/0405/221284.html Detainees Escape From U.S. Military Camp: KATV]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.opinionjournal.com/editorial/feature.html?id=110006725 As Bad as the Nazis? {{Multiple issues|{{expert-subject|date=October 2014|reason=A religion-related contributor needs to qualify if this is as notable as it needs to be for a religion subject}}{{cleanup-reorganize|date=October 2014}}}}
{{Main|Abolitionism}}
Although many Enlightenment philosophers opposed slavery, it was Christian activists, attracted by strong religious elements, who initiated and organized an abolitionist movement. <ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://www.jubilee-centre.org/document.php?id=51 |title=The abolition of the slave trade: Christian conscience and political action |access-date=12 September 2009}}</ref> Throughout Europe and the United States, Christians, usually from 'un-institutional' Christian faith movements, not directly connected with traditional state churches, or "[[non-conformist]]" believers within established churches, were to be found at the forefront of the abolitionist movements.<ref name="auto"/><ref>Roger Anstey, "Slavery and the Protestant Ethic", ''Historical Reflections'' 1979 6(1): 157–181. Pp. 157–172.</ref>
In particular, the effects of the [[Second Great Awakening]] resulted in many evangelicals working to see the theoretical Christian view, that all people are essentially equal, made more of a practical reality. Freedom of expression within the Western world also helped in enabling opportunity to express their position. Prominent among these [[abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolitionists]] was [[Member of Parliament|Parliamentarian]] [[William Wilberforce]] in England, who wrote in his diary when he was 28 that, "God Almighty has set before me two great objects, the suppression of the Slave Trade and Reformation of Morals."<ref>quoted in Piper, 2002, p. 37)</ref> With others he labored, despite determined opposition, to finally abolish the British [[slave trade]]. English preacher [[Charles Spurgeon]] had some of his sermons burned in America due to his censure of slavery, calling it "the foulest blot" and which "may have to be washed out in blood."<ref>The Christian Cabinet, December 14, 1859</ref> Methodist founder [[John Wesley]] denounced human bondage as "the sum of all villainies," and detailed its abuses.<ref>Thoughts Upon Slavery, John Wesley, Published in the year 1774, John Wesley: Holiness of Heart and Life, 1996 Ruth A. Daugherty</ref> In Georgia, primitive Methodists united with brethren elsewhere in condemning slavery. Many evangelical leaders in the United States such as [[Presbyterian]] [[Charles Finney]] and [[Theodore Weld]], and women such as [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]] (daughter of abolitionist [[Lyman Beecher]]) and [[Sojourner Truth]] motivated hearers to support [[abolitionism in the United States|abolition]]. Finney preached that slavery was a moral sin, and so supported its elimination. "I had made up my mind on the question of slavery, and was exceedingly anxious to arouse public attention to the subject. In my prayers and preaching, I so often alluded to slavery, and denounced it.<ref>Charles G. Finney, Memoirs (New York: A.S. Barnes, 1876), 324</ref> Repentance from slavery was required of souls, once enlightened of the subject, while continued support of the system incurred "the greatest guilt" upon them.<ref>[http://www.gospeltruth.net/1852OE/520818_guilt_ignorance.htm Guilt modified by ignorance—anti-slavery duties, by President Finney] 1852</ref>
[[Quaker]]s in particular were early leaders in [[abolitionism]]. In 1688 Dutch Quakers in Germantown, Pennsylvania, sent an antislavery petition to the Monthly Meeting of Quakers. By 1727 British Quakers had expressed their official disapproval of the slave trade.<ref>London Yearly Meeting minutes, Vol. 6, 457–458</ref> Three Quaker abolitionists, Benjamin Lay, John Woolman, and Anthony Benezet, devoted their lives to the abolitionist effort from the 1730s to the 1760s, with Lay founding the Negro School in 1770, which would serve more than 250 pupils.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/5913/Abolition-Movement.html|title=Abolition Movement - EARLY ANTISLAVERY EFFORTS, EARLY EFFORTS OF BLACKS, REVOLUTIONARY ERA ABOLITIONISM, NORTHERN ABOLITIONISM|author=|date=|website=Encyclopedia.Jrank.org|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref> In June 1783 a petition from the London Yearly Meeting and signed by over 300 Quakers was presented to Parliament protesting the slave trade.<ref>London Yearly Meeting minutes, Vol. 17, 298–307</ref>
In 1787 the [[Society for Effecting the Abolition of the Slave Trade]] was formed, with 9 of the 12 founder members being Quakers. During the same year, William Wilberforce was persuaded to take up their cause; as an MP, Wilberforce was able to introduce a bill to abolish the slave trade. Wilberforce first attempted to abolish the trade in 1791, but could only muster half the necessary votes; however, after transferring his support to the [[Whig (British political party)|Whigs]], it became an election issue. Abolitionist pressure had changed popular opinion, and in the 1806 election enough abolitionists entered parliament for Wilberforce to be able to see the passing of the [[Slave Trade Act 1807]]. The [[Royal Navy]] subsequently declared that the slave trade was equal to piracy, the [[West Africa Squadron]] choosing to seize ships involved in the transfer of slaves and liberate the slaves on board, effectively crippling the transatlantic trade. Through abolitionist efforts, popular opinion continued to mount against slavery, and [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833|in 1833 slavery itself was outlawed]] throughout the [[British Empire]] – at that time containing roughly 1/6 of the world's population (rising to 1/4 towards the end of the century).
In the United States, the abolition movement faced much opposition. [[Bertram Wyatt-Brown]] notes that the appearance of the Christian abolitionist movement "with its religious ideology alarmed newsmen, politicians, and ordinary citizens. They angrily predicted the endangerment of secular democracy, the mongrelization, as it was called, of white society, and the destruction of the federal union. Speakers at huge rallies and editors of conservative papers in the North denounced these newcomers to radical reform as the same old “church-and-state” zealots, who tried to shut down post offices, taverns, carriage companies, shops, and other public places on Sundays. Mob violence sometimes ensued."{{Cite quote|date=June 2017}}
A postal campaign in 1835 by the [[American Anti-Slavery Society]] (AA-SS) – founded by [[African-American]] Presbyterian clergyman [[Theodore S. Wright]] – sent bundles of tracts and newspapers (over 100,000) to prominent clerical, legal, and political figures throughout the whole country, and culminated in massive demonstrations throughout the North and South.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/tserve/nineteen/nkeyinfo/amabrel.htm|title=American Abolitionism and Religion, Divining America, TeacherServe©, National Humanities Center|author=|date=|website=NationalHumanitiesCenter.org|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref> In attempting to stop these mailings, New York Postmaster Samuel L. Gouverneur unsuccessfully requested the AA-SS to cease sending it to the South. He therefore decided that he would “aid in preserving the public peace” by refusing to allow the mails to carry abolition pamphlets to the South himself, with the new [[United States Postmaster General|Postmaster General]] [[Amos Kendall]] affirming, even though he admitted he had no legal authority to do so.<ref>Jennifer Rose, ''The Culture of Honor: How Slaveholders Responded to the Abolitionist Mail Crisis of 1835'', p. 60</ref><ref>[http://colfa.utsa.edu/users/jreynolds/Textbooks/Abolition/Abolitionists%20Mussey.htm David S. Mussey, "The American Adventure"], 2 vols. New York, 1980</ref><ref>American Mobbing, 1828–1861 By David Grimsted</ref><ref>Schlesinger ''Age of Jackson'', p. 190</ref> This resulted in the AA-SS resorting to other and clandestine means of dissemination.
Despite such determined opposition, many Methodist, Baptist, and Presbyterian members freed their slaves and sponsored black congregations, in which many black ministers encouraged slaves to believe that freedom could be gained during their lifetime. After a great [[Christian revival|revival]] occurred in 1801 at Cane Ridge, Kentucky, American Methodists made anti-slavery sentiments a condition of church membership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ket.org/underground/history/westexpansion.htm|title=Kentucky’s Underground Railroad: Passage to Freedom|author=|date=|website=KET.org|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref> Abolitionist writings, such as "A Condensed Anti-Slavery Bible Argument" (1845) by George Bourne,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/church/bourne/bourne.html|title=George Bourne, 1780-1845. A Condensed Anti-Slavery Bible Argument; By a Citizen of Virginia.|author=|date=|website=docsouth.UNC.edu|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref> and "God Against Slavery" (1857) by George B. Cheever,<ref>See also "The guilt of slavery and the crime of slaveholding, demonstrated from the Hebrew and Greek scriptures"</ref> used the Bible, logic and reason extensively in contending against the institution of slavery, and in particular the chattel form of it as seen in the South. In Cheever's speech entitled, "The Fire and Hammer of God’s Word Against the Sin of Slavery", his desire for eliminating the crime of slaveholding is clear, as he goes so far as to address it to the President.
Other Protestant missionaries of the Great Awakening initially opposed slavery in the South, but by the early decades of the 19th century, many Baptist and Methodist preachers in the South had come to an accommodation with it in order to evangelize the farmers and workers. Disagreements between the newer way of thinking and the old often created schisms within denominations at the time. Differences in views toward slavery resulted in the Baptist and Methodist churches dividing into regional associations by the beginning of the Civil War.<ref>Dooley 11–15; McKivigan 27 (ritualism), 30, 51, 191, Osofsky; ''ANB'' [[Leonidas Polk]]</ref>
Roman Catholic statements also became increasingly vehement against slavery during this era. In 1741 [[Pope Benedict XIV]] condemned slavery generally. In 1815 [[Pope Pius VII]] demanded of the Congress of Vienna the suppression of the slave trade. In the Bull of Canonization of [[Peter Claver]], one of the most illustrious adversaries of slavery, [[Pope Pius IX]] branded the "supreme villainy" (''summum nefas'') of the slave traders;<ref name=Catholic>{{cite encyclopedia | last = Allard | first = Paul | title = Slavery and Christianity | encyclopedia = Catholic Enycyclopedia | volume = XIV | publisher = Robert Appleton Company | location = New York |year=1912 | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14036a.htm | access-date = 4 February 2006 }}</ref>
In 1839 [[Pope Gregory XVI]] condemned the slave trade in ''[[In supremo apostolatus]]'';<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.papalencyclicals.net/Greg16/g16sup.htm |title=In supremo apostolatus|access-date=12 September 2009}}</ref> and in 1888 [[Pope Leo XIII]] condemned slavery in [[In Plurimis]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.papalencyclicals.net/Leo13/l13abl.htm |title=IN PLURIMIS – ON THE ABOLITION OF SLAVERY |access-date=12 September 2009}}</ref>
[[Roman Catholic]] efforts extended to the Americas. The Roman Catholic leader of the Irish in Ireland, [[Daniel O'Connell]], supported the abolition of slavery in the British Empire and in America. With the black abolitionist [[Charles Lenox Remond]], and the temperance priest [[Theobald Mathew (temperance reformer)|Theobold Mathew]], he organized a petition with 60,000 signatures urging the Irish of the United States to support abolition. O'Connell also spoke in the United States for abolition.
Preceding such, and while not explicitly expressing an abolitionist point of view, the Portuguese [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] [[Gaspar da Cruz]] in 1569 strongly criticized the Portuguese traffic in Chinese slaves, explaining that any arguments by the slave traders that they "legally" purchased already-enslaved children were bogus.<ref>{{citation |first=Charles Ralph |last=Boxer|first2= Galeote |last2=Pereira|first3= Gaspar da |last3=Cruz|first4= Martín de |last4=Rada |author-link=C. R. Boxer |publisher=Printed for the Hakluyt Society |year=1953 |title=South China in the sixteenth century: being the narratives of Galeote Pereira, Fr. Gaspar da Cruz, O.P. [and] Fr. Martín de Rada, O.E.S.A. (1550–1575) |series=Issue 106 of Works issued by the Hakluyt Society |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ImoTAAAAIAAJ |pages=151–152}} (Includes an English translation of Gaspar da Cruz's entire book, with [[C.R. Boxer]]'s comments)</ref>
In 1917, the Roman Catholic Church's canon law was officially expanded to specify that "selling a human being into slavery or for any other evil purpose" is a crime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/chr_slav2.htm|title=The final abolition of slavery in Christianity lands|author=|date=|website=www.ReligiousTolerance.org|access-date=24 June 2017}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox civilian attack |title = Clackamas Town Center shooting |image=Clackamas Town Center shooting memorial.jpg |caption=Memorial to victims of shooting at mall entrance |location = 12000 SE 82nd Avenue
{{nowrap|[[Clackamas, Oregon]], U.S.}} |coordinates = {{coord|45.436|-122.574|display=inline,title|scale:50000_region:US_type:event}} |date = {{start date|2012|12|11}} |time = {{nowrap|3:28 p.m. – 3:50 p.m.[http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2013/12/clackamas_shooting_a_year_late.html "Clackamas shooting: A year later, impact of the tragedy still being felt at the mall"]}} |timezone = [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |type = [[Shooting]], [[murder-suicide]] |fatalities = 3 (including the perpetrator) |injuries = 1 |weapons = [[AR-15]] [[rifle]] |perp = Jacob Tyler Roberts |dfen = Nick Meli }} On December 11, 2012, a shooting occurred at the [[Clackamas Town Center]] in unincorporated [[Clackamas County, Oregon|Clackamas County]], outside the city of [[Portland, Oregon]], United States. The gunman, 22-year-old Jacob Tyler Roberts, ran into the shopping center wearing tactical clothing and a [[hockey mask]] and opened fire on shoppers and employees with a stolen [[AR-15]]. He fired a total of 17 shots, killing two people and seriously wounding a third. Having attempted to reload his weapon and dropping three magazines, Roberts entered a stairwell and committed [[suicide]] after descending one level. He had no connection to any of his victims, and it was believed to be a random act of violence.{{cite news|last=Carson|first=Teresa|title=Oregon mall shooting appears to be lone, random rampage|date=December 12, 2012|newspaper=[[Reuters]] ''via [[Chicago Tribune]]''|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-usa-shooting-oregonbre8bb017-20121211,0,4763419.story}}{{cite web|author=Lydia Warren |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2246748/Jacob-Tyler-Roberts-Gunman-Oregon-mall-shooting-identified.html |title=Jacob Tyler Roberts: Gunman in Oregon mall shooting identified |work=Daily Mail |date=December 13, 2012 |accessdate=2013-01-05}} The Clackamas Town Center has a posted policy of prohibiting firearms on the premises.[http://www.clackamastowncenter.com/en/code-of-conduct.html Code of Conduct] ==Details== ===Prior to the shooting=== [[Image:1973 Colt AR15 SP1.jpg|thumb|left|1973 [[AR-15]], one of many models of the semi-automatic rifle used by the shooter]] Sometime prior to the shooting, Roberts is stated to have stolen a [[AR-15]] [[rifle]] from an acquaintance. Immediately before the shooting, he visited a friend who lived two miles away from the Clackamas Town Center, smoked [[marijuana]] with him, and claimed that he was moving to [[Hawaii]].[http://www.wsema.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/13_-_CTC_SHT_WSEMA.pdf "Clackamas Town Center Shooting: After-Action Report"] He drove to the mall sometime later and parked at the south side between [[Macy's]] and [[Chipotle Mexican Grill]]. He ran into the mall through Macy's department store at 3:28 p.m., wearing a white hockey mask and a [[Individual Integrated Fighting System|load-bearing vest]] and armed with the AR-15. He was also carrying five loaded magazines, one of which he accidentally dropped in the parking lot while entering the mall. Roberts legally bought four additional standard capacity 30-round ammunition magazines and the ammunition to fill them at three local stores, including a [[Walmart]], The Gunbroker, and Wholesale Sports Outdoor Outfitters. When he stole the unsecured AR-15 from a friend, it was loaded with a standard capacity 30-round ammunition magazine. Between 8,000 and 10,000 people were inside the mall at the time. People who first saw him run into the mall believed the tactical clothing and hockey mask were a [[paintball]] outfit and that the rifle was a toy.[http://www.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/index.ssf/2012/12/clackamas_town_center_shooting_61.html "Clackamas Town Center shooting: 22 minutes of chaos and terror as a gunman meanders through the mall"] ===Shooting=== Standing in a large atrium, Roberts first opened fire at the mall's food court that was across from him at his left. The first person shot was 54-year-old shopper Cindy Ann Yuille, a hospice nurse and mother of two who was shot in the back; she died despite efforts of bystanders to treat her wound. 15-year-old Kristina Shevchenko, who was walking through the mall with her friend to reach the Town Center MAX station, was the second person to be shot; she received a bullet to the chest, but she survived and made it out of the mall, where she was treated for her gunshot wound. The final victim was 46-year-old father of two and youth sports coach Steven Forsyth, who was sitting by a rented [[kiosk]] and talking with his father on his cell phone when he was shot in the head and killed. At this point, hundreds of people fled the mall after hearing the gunshots, but many remained inside and dashed to cover. Roberts headed further toward the food court, firing at 16-year-old employee Alina Pavlenko, who was over 100 feet away, but missed. He also dropped three other magazines in his possession. He then turned back and headed toward a [[JCPenney]] store. He attempted to reload the AR-15 at that point, but was unable to do so, the weapon having apparently jammed. During that time, Nick Meli, a [[concealed carry]] permit holder, drew his [[Glock 22]], claimed to have taken aim at Roberts, but did not fire since there was a bystander behind Roberts. Meli claims that Roberts saw him and that this may have contributed to Roberts' decision to commit suicide.{{cite web|title=Clackamas mall shooter faced man with concealed weapon|url=http://www.kgw.com/video/news/clackamas-mall-shooter-faced-man-with-concealed-weapon/283-606213|website=kgw.com|publisher=KGW}} ===Shooting ends=== Roberts then ran into a back storage corridor, where he encountered employee Rok Sang Kim, who had returned from recycling boxes and therefore hadn't heard the gunfire. Roberts pointed the rifle at him, but didn't shoot him, instead running down a flight of stairs onto a lower floor. There, he committed suicide at 3:50 p.m. In the chaos of the first few minutes after the shooting, there were expectations of mass casualties. Police responded to the scene minutes later and spent the following hours searching the mall for hiding civilians, injured victims, and a possible second shooter, while dozens of ambulances arrived with the expectations of treating dozens of wounded victims, but treated only Kristina Shevchenko for a serious gunshot wound. Roberts fired only seventeen rounds during the entire shooting, including the one to kill himself. An additional 128 rounds were found in the magazines he dropped and on his person. By the next day, the mall was cleared of civilians, but continued to remain under lock-down. It is believed Roberts targeted random people and did not have a specific target in mind.{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Michael|title='I have lived one crazy life so far,' Oregon mall gunman says on Facebook|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=December 12, 2012|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/12/us/oregon-mall-gunman-profile/index.html?hpt=hp_t1 |accessdate=December 12, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Ian|last2=Raftery|first2=Isolde|title=Two people shot to death at mall in Portland, Oregon; gunman also dies|date=December 11, 2012|publisher=[[NBC News]]|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/12/11/15849093-two-people-shot-to-death-at-mall-in-portland-oregon-gunman-also-dies?lite |accessdate=December 19, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Bella|first=Rick|title=Clackamas Town Center shooting: Killer was Jacob Tyler Roberts; fatalities were Steve Forsyth, Cindy Ann Yuille|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]] ''via [[OregonLive.com]]''|date=December 12, 2012|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/index.ssf/2012/12/clackamas_town_center_shooting_13.htm|accessdate=December 19, 2012}} ===Victims=== Two people were killed in the shooting, 54-year-old Cindy Ann Yuille and 45-year-old Steven Forsyth. A third person, 15-year-old Kristina Shevchenko, was shot in the side of the chest and seriously injured, but survived. Several others also suffered minor bruises and scrapes suffered while fleeing. ==Perpetrator== {{Infobox murderer |name = Jacob Tyler Roberts |image = File:Jacob-Tyler-Roberts.jpg |image_size = |caption = Jacob Tyler Roberts |birth_name = |birth_date = March 16, 1990 |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]], U.S.}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|12|11|1990|03|16}} |death_place = {{nowrap|[[Clackamas, Oregon]], U.S.}} |body_discovered = {{nowrap|[[Clackamas Town Center]], [[Clackamas, Oregon|Clackamas]], [[Oregon]], U.S.}} |death_cause = Suicide by [[gunshot wound]] |resting_place = |residence = [[Lents, Portland, Oregon]], United States |nationality = American |motive = Unknown }} '''Jacob Tyler Roberts''' (March 16, 1990 – December 11, 2012) was identified as the sole perpetrator of the shooting. He lived in the [[Lents, Portland, Oregon|Lents]] neighborhood in southeast Portland. Roberts was raised by his aunt Tami Roberts; his biological mother, Teresa Anne Roberts, died from cancer in February 1993, shortly before his third birthday. Court records and family indicated that the identity of his father is unknown. He had been estranged from his aunt Tami Roberts since the time he was 18 years of age, though the aunt declined to comment on the reason, saying only that it was unrelated to an $18,000 inheritance from Roberts's grandmother that court documents allegedly show Tami Roberts misappropriated.{{cite web|last=Dubois|first=Steven|title=Jacob Tyler Roberts' Injury Dashed Oregon Mall Shooter's Hopes Of Being Marine|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/14/jacob-tyler-roberts-broken-foot-marines_n_2299611.html|work=Huffington Post Crime|publisher=Huffington Post|author2=Rachel La Corte|date=14 December 2012}} He attended [[Milwaukie High School]] in [[Milwaukie, Oregon]] for the first three years and later transferred during his senior year to [[Oregon City High School]] in [[Oregon City, Oregon]], graduating in 2008. He attended [[Clackamas Community College]] in 2009. Two years prior to the shooting, Roberts worked at a [[gyro (food)|gyro]] restaurant in downtown Portland,{{cite news|date=December 12, 2012|last=Anderson|first=Jennifer|title=Shooter: 'I'm the kind of person who's going to do what I want'|newspaper=[[Portland Tribune]]|url= http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/124731-shooter--im-the-kind-of-person-whos-going-to-do-what-i-want}} where he was well-liked by his employer. Roberts lived with a few roommates in a house ten minutes away from the shopping center. He had plans of joining the [[United States Marine Corps]], but he abandoned these dreams after a bicycle accident that broke his foot. Within a week prior to the shooting, he had broken up with his girlfriend, sold his belongings, resigned from his job, and alleged to his friends and colleagues that he was planning to move to [[Hawaii]]. He also purchased at least four magazines and hundreds of rounds of ammunition from local stores during that same timeline. ==Reaction== When [[U.S. President|President]] [[Barack Obama]] delivered a speech regarding the [[Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting]], he mentioned other shooting rampages that occurred in the U.S. within previous months, including the incident at the Clackamas Town Center.{{cite news|title=Connecticut school shooting: Barack Obama calls for 'meaningful action, regardless of politics' |date=December 15, 2012|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/barackobama/9747040/Connecticut-school-shooting-Barack-Obama-calls-for-meaningful-action-regardless-of-politics.html}} On March 28, 2013, a [[candlelight vigil]] was held at the mall, organized against gun violence and one of more than 120 events held nationwide to commemorate the National Day of Action to Reduce Gun Violence.[http://www.oregonlive.com/clackamascounty/index.ssf/2013/03/candlelight_vigil_against_gun.html "Candlelight vigil against gun violence to be held tonight at Clackamas Town Center"] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clackamas Town Center shooting}} [[Category:2012 in Oregon]] [[Category:2012 mass shootings in the United States]] [[Category:Mass shootings in the United States]] [[Category:2012 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Attacks in the United States in 2012]] [[Category:Attacks on buildings and structures in the United States]] [[Category:Clackamas County, Oregon]] [[Category:Crimes in Oregon]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Oregon]] [[Category:Defensive gun use]] [[Category:Mass shootings in Oregon]] [[Category:Murder in Oregon]] [[Category:Murder–suicides in Oregon]] [[Category:Shopping mall attacks]] [[Category:Suicides by firearm in Oregon]]
